chapter.para: XProc uses XPath expressions to compute the values of variables and options, to select the branches of a p:choose, to select nodes for processing, etc. The XProc specification allows implementors to support either XPath 1.0 or XPath 2.0. XML Calabash supports XPath 2.0.

Whether your processor supports XPath 1.0 or XPath 2.0, XProc processors provide several additional functions that you can use in XPath expressions. These functions are available whereever the XProc processor evaluates an expression.

section.title: p:system-property
section.para: The p:system-property function returns information about the processor.
The $property must have the lexical form of a QName. If a prefix is used, it must be in the in-scope namespaces where the expression occurs.
The following system properties are always available:

listitem.para: Returns a unique string that identifies this run of the processor. This string will satisfy the constraints of an XML Name so it can easily be used as an identifier, for example, in a filename.
Returns a string which identifies the current language.
Returns a string containing the name of the implementation.
Returns a string identifying the version of the implementation.
Returns a string which identifies the vendor of the processor.
Returns a URI which identifies the vendor of the processor. Often, this is the URI of the vendor’s web site.
Returns the version or versions of XProc implemented by the processor as a space-separated list. At the time of this writing, only “1.0” is defined.
Returns the version or versions of XPath implemented by the processor for evaluating XPath expressions on XProc elements.
Returns “true” if the implementation supports passing PSVI annotations between steps, “false” otherwise.

section.para: Processors may support additional system properties. If an unrecognized property name is passed to p:system-property, an empty string is returned.

section.title: p:step-available
section.para: The p:step-available function tests whether or not a particular step type can be used in this pipeline.
The $step-type must have the lexical form of a QName. If a prefix is used, it must be in the in-scope namespaces where the expression occurs.
If steps of the specified type are supported by the pipeline (that is, if they’re supported by the processor and declared by this pipeline), the function returns true, otherwise it returns false.

section.title: p:value-available
section.para: If a pipeline specifies an option that is neither required nor has a default value, then it’s possible that the caller has not provided any value for that option. The p:value-available function allows you to test for that case.
section.synopsis: p:value-available($option-name as xs:string, $fail-if-unknown as xs:boolean) as xs:boolean
section.para: The $option-name must be the name of an in-scope option. The function returns true if it has a value, false otherwise. If $fail-if-unknown is provided and is true, then the function will raise an error if the value is not provided.
